items.title: 'Tentacles of fire' captured by satellites during bushfire crisis
items.description: Hundreds of images captured by an orbiting weather satellite, and stitched together by the ABC, show the scale and destructive force of the Victorian bushfires.

items.title: Households 'paid to pare back' demand when power grid strains
items.description: In a move labelled a sign of the times, energy firm AGL was last week offering customers money to cut use during a heatwave.

items.title: What is in the government’s new hate speech laws?
items.description: Parliament will return early next week to debate new hate speech laws. But what exactly does the legislation include?

items.title: Fight brewing on national gun reform as states splinter on party lines
items.description: A split is emerging at a state level over the government's plan to establish a national gun buyback scheme following the Bondi terror attack.

items.title: How two 'foolhardy' blokes conquered Australia's most dangerous stretch of water
items.description: With whisky and lollies for sustenance and pigeons their only means of communication, Steve Harris and Doug Fleming crossed Bass Strait in a 4.5m dinghy in 1974.

items.title: Great Ocean Road communties recovering after historic deluge, flash flooding
items.description: Record-breaking rains turned into surging floodwaters in towns along Victoria's coast on Thursday, sweeping cars into the ocean and inundating two caravan parks.

items.title: Canada and China sign trade roadmap as Carney makes first Beijing visit in 8 years

featured_image.name: Canadian prime minister visits China after nearly a decade of tense ...

items.description:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and China's top officials signaled a major shift in bilateral relations Thursday as the two countries signed an economic and trade cooperation roadmap alongside six initial agreements covering energy, food safety, and other sectors during the first visit to Beijing by a Canadian leader in eight years.

Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi characterized Carney's four-day state visit as a "turning point" in ties between the two nations, telling Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Anita Anand that the progress would "open up new prospects for bilateral relations" amid what he described as "unprecedented and complex changes taking place in the world."[1][2][3]

items.title: Rice quantum simulator reveals how vibrations drive energy flow in molecules

featured_image.name: Quantum simulator reveals how vibrations steer energy flow ...

items.description:
Researchers at Rice University have built a quantum device capable of simulating molecular vibrations and directly observing how energy moves from one part of a molecule to another, findings that could deepen understanding of natural processes like photosynthesis and improve designs for solar energy technology.

The work, published Dec. 5 in Nature Communications, marks the first time scientists have used trapped-ion technology to simulate a two-mode molecular system while independently controlling energy loss to the environment, according to the research team.[1][2]

items.title: Trump threatens to invoke Insurrection Act over Minnesota anti-ICE protests
items.description: Such a move would allow the president to deploy troops to quell persistent protests in the city of Minneapolis, where two shootings connected to immigration crackdowns are fuelling public anger.

items.title: Space economy markets forecast to double by 2030

featured_image.name: Investors pour record $3.5 billion into space as investors ... - Reuters

items.description:
Multiple sectors of the space economy are projected to surge over the next five years as governments and private investors pour unprecedented funding into satellite services, orbital manufacturing, space habitats, and rescue operations.

New market research reports released January 15, 2026, by ResearchAndMarkets.com detail growth trajectories across several emerging space economy segments. The space currency and economy market is forecast to grow from $1.91 billion in 2026 to $3.8 billion by 2030, while in-space manufacturing, servicing, and transportation is expected to expand from $2.6 billion to $5.23 billion during the same period. Space habitat development is projected to reach $11.54 billion by 2030, growing at a compound annual growth rate of 20.8%.[1][2][3]

items.title: TSMC posts record profit as AI chip demand surges

featured_image.name: TSMC Q4 profit poised to soar 27% as AI demand drives growth ...

items.description:
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the world's largest contract chipmaker, reported record fourth-quarter results on Thursday, with net profit surging 35% year-over-year to NT$505.74 billion ($16 billion), exceeding analyst expectations and fueling a rally across global semiconductor stocks.

The Taiwanese chipmaker announced revenue of NT$1.046 trillion ($33.7 billion) for the quarter ending December 31, marking a 20.5% increase from the previous year. TSMC also revealed plans to substantially increase capital expenditure to between $52 billion and $56 billion in 2026, up from $40.9 billion last year, and projected approximately 30% revenue growth for the full year.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: 'Night owls' less likely to find antidepressants effective: new study
items.description: A major Australian study finds standard antidepressants are not effective for around 20 per cent of people, who may need alternative treatments.

items.title: Prometheus claims new process cuts synthetic jet fuel costs by 80%

featured_image.name: Prometheus Just Changed Energy and Fuels Forever

items.description:
Santa Cruz-based Prometheus Fuels has announced what it calls a revolutionary method to produce synthetic jet fuel and diesel from electricity and air, claiming the process reduces e-fuel production costs by more than 80 percent compared to century-old Fischer-Tropsch technology.[1][2][3]

The announcement, made on January 14, marks the first public disclosure of the company's proprietary electrochemical pathway for producing synthetic paraffinic kerosene, the basis for sustainable aviation fuel and e-diesel. According to the company, the process is the first in history to produce kerosene from electricity and atmospheric CO2 without using hydrogen.[3][4][1]

items.title: AI pioneer Bengio says he's confident safe AI is possible

featured_image.name: AI 'godfather' Yoshua Bengio says he's found a fix for AI's biggest ...

items.description:
Yoshua Bengio, the Turing Award-winning AI pioneer often called one of the "godfathers" of artificial intelligence, says his latest research has dramatically shifted his outlook on the future of superintelligent AI. In a recent interview with Fortune, Bengio expressed renewed optimism about humanity's ability to build safe AI systems, citing progress at his nonprofit organization LawZero.[1][2][3]

"Because of the work I've been doing at LawZero, especially since we created it, I'm now very confident that it is possible to build AI systems that don't have hidden goals, hidden agendas," Bengio told Fortune, adding that his optimism has increased "by a big margin" over the past year.[4][2]

items.title: Millions of accounts culled days after social media ban started, data shows
items.description: More than 4.7 million Australian social media accounts have been deactivated since laws banning children aged under 16 took effect in December, according to data released by the government.

items.title: New self-healing composite could extend aircraft lifespans to centuries

featured_image.name: Research: Overcoming longstanding challenges for self ...

items.description:
Researchers at North Carolina State University have developed a self-healing composite material capable of repairing itself more than 1,000 times, a breakthrough that could extend the lifespan of aircraft wings, wind turbine blades, and spacecraft components from decades to centuries.

The study, published this week in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, demonstrates what researchers call "century-scale fracture recovery" in fiber-reinforced polymer composites—materials prized for their high strength-to-weight ratio but long plagued by a failure mode known as delamination.[1][2]

items.title: Study finds ocean damage nearly doubles climate cost estimates

featured_image.name: Study Finds Ocean Impacts Nearly Double Economic Cost of ...

items.description:
The economic toll of climate change on the world's oceans has been vastly underestimated, according to new research that for the first time puts a price tag on marine ecosystem degradation—findings that emerge alongside a separate study warning that proposed climate engineering solutions carry their own risks to ocean life.

Research published Wednesday in the journal Nature Climate Change by scientists at Scripps Institution of Oceanography at UC San Diego found that factoring ocean damage into climate calculations nearly doubles the global cost of carbon dioxide emissions. The study introduces what researchers call the "blue" social cost of carbon, adding $46.2 per ton of CO2 to existing estimates, bringing the total to $97.2 per ton—a 91% increase.[1][2]

items.title: Denmark says White House talks failed to shift Trump's Greenland stance

featured_image.name: Can the US put a price tag on Greenland?

items.description:
Despite President Donald Trump's intensifying push to gain control of Greenland, experts warn that the Arctic territory's severe climate, remote geography, and absent infrastructure pose obstacles that no change in sovereignty could overcome. The island's vast mineral wealth remains locked beneath ice and rock that have defied extraction efforts for decades.

"If you're going to go to Greenland for its minerals, you're talking billions upon billions upon billions of dollars and extremely long time before anything ever comes of it," mineral industry analyst Louis Marchese told Fortune, offering a sobering assessment of the mining reality.[1]

items.title: Amazon opens sovereign cloud in Germany to ease EU data fears

featured_image.name: AWS seeks to allay security fears with new European ...

items.description:
Amazon on Thursday launched its AWS European Sovereign Cloud, a new independent cloud infrastructure designed specifically for Europe that is physically and legally separate from the company's other data centers worldwide. The move addresses growing European concerns about data sovereignty and the dominance of U.S. technology companies in the region's cloud computing market.

The first AWS Region of the sovereign cloud opened in the German state of Brandenburg, which surrounds Berlin. Amazon plans to invest more than €7.8 billion in the AWS European Sovereign Cloud in Germany through 2040, according to the company, with the investment expected to support an average of 2,800 full-time equivalent jobs annually and add approximately €17.2 billion to Germany's GDP.[1][2][3]

items.title: 'Died in the hands of her father': Negin is one of thousands of Iranians killed
items.description: Like so many Iranian Australians, Morteza Khandani has been desperate for any news of his family in Iran. Two days ago, he was able to confirm the worst. His niece, Negin Ghadimi, had been killed in anti-government protests.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
